title: Contraception's Voluntary Empire: Health and Society in South India before the Development State
abstractText: Contraception's Voluntary Empire outlines the overlapping stories of the international birth control movement in south India, and the south Indian indigenization of international birth control. Because the late colonial Indian state remained notably hesitant to extend its welfare measures to include the provision of contraception or contraception advice, the south Indian history of conception is a story about the mixed economy of late colonial welfare. My aim is to make sense of this mixed economy by outlining both the role of the state as well as the diverse local actors who animated the south Indian indigenisation of contraception.
